sections.title: Shorthand props
sections.content: Because using the field component in its full form can be verbose and repetitive, all form controls in flux allow you pass a label and a description parameter directly. Under the hood, they will be wrapped in a field with an error component automatically.

sections.title: With trailing description
sections.content: Position the field description directly below the input.
examples: <flux:field> <flux:label>Password</flux:label> <flux:input type="password" /> <flux:error name="password" /> <flux:description>Must be at least 8 characters long, include an uppercase letter, a number, and a special character.</flux:description></flux:field><!-- Alternative shorthand syntax... --><flux:input type="password" label="Password" description:trailing="Must be at least 8 characters long, include an uppercase letter, a number, and a special character."/>

sections.title: With badge
sections.content: Badges allow you to enhance a field with additional information such as being "required" or "optional" when it might not be expected.
examples: <flux:field> <flux:label badge="Required">Email</flux:label> <flux:input type="email" required /> <flux:error name="email" /></flux:field><flux:field> <flux:label badge="Optional">Phone number</flux:label> <flux:input type="phone" placeholder="(555) 555-5555" mask="(999) 999-9999" /> <flux:error name="phone" /></flux:field>

sections.title: Split layout
sections.content: Display multiple fields horizontally in the same row.
